linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil will play an increasingly important role in the Asia Pacific's energy supply, partly due to the rapid adoption of road vehicles in the developing countries (IEA 2017b). China accounts for nearly half of the region's oil production, but the country's oil production peaked in 2015. Other major producers in the region have seen flat to declining production since 2010 with the exception of Thailand which has seen modest but steady growth (Figure 1). Total oil production in the Asia Pacific region is approximately 8.7% of the world's production in an area representing more than 35% of the world's oil consumption. Asia Pacific oil reserves represent only about 3% of the world's total in an area with more than 50% of the world's population (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Asia Pacific oil production (KBOPD) (Left) and relative proportions of 2018 Asia Pacific oil reserves (Right) (Source: British Petroleum 2018)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Asia Pacific oil production (KBOPD) (Left) and relative proportions of 2018 Asia Pacific oil reserves (Right) (Source: British Petroleum 2018)

linkTarget.bib: British Petroleum 2018. BP statistical review of world energy 2018. British Petroleum, London.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil production for the entire Asia Pacific region in 2017 of 7,879 KBOPD is down 6.25% from the peak production in the region just two years earlier. Drilling activity in the region remains depressed compared to most international regions (Figure 3). Only Latin America had a more pronounced decrease in drilling activity than did Asia Pacific. Asia Pacific drilling has increasingly focused on natural gas projects. The region represents about 10% of global gas reserves (Figure 2). China and Japan lead the region in gas consumption with strong gas growth in India, South Korea and Australia.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Asia Pacific gas production (bcfd) (Left) and relative proportions of 2018 Asia Pacific gas reserves (Right) (Source: British Petroleum 2018)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Asia Pacific gas production (bcfd) (Left) and relative proportions of 2018 Asia Pacific gas reserves (Right) (Source: British Petroleum 2018)

linkTarget.bib: British Petroleum 2018. BP statistical review of world energy 2018. British Petroleum, London.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil production for the entire Asia Pacific region in 2017 of 7,879 KBOPD is down 6.25% from the peak production in the region just two years earlier. Drilling activity in the region remains depressed compared to most international regions (Figure 3). Only Latin America had a more pronounced decrease in drilling activity than did Asia Pacific. Asia Pacific drilling has increasingly focused on natural gas projects. The region represents about 10% of global gas reserves (Figure 2). China and Japan lead the region in gas consumption with strong gas growth in India, South Korea and Australia.

The top 17 exporters accounted for more than 90% of the oil imports to the region. The top five importers in the region account for about 95% of imported oil, and this share is increasingly dominated by China and India (Figure 4,Figure 5). China is now the world's largest importer of crude oil importing 9.7 MMBPD. India, Japan and South Korea combined to import 10.81 MMBPD. These four countries import a total of 20.53 million BOPD of which more than 1.7 MMBPD is imported from Iran. For comparison, the US imported 7 MMBPD of crude oil and exported 2.5 MMPBD of products, and all of Europe imported 9.9 MMPD of crude oil and 0.9 MMBPD of products.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Volume of crude oil imports into Asia Pacific nations. Volumentric shares are indicated by thickness of stream lines, Asia Pacific nations are shaded grey and exporting nations are shaded in bright colors. Inset bar chart describes the relative contributions of each exporting nation to Asia Pacific nations. Less significant exporters are binned together into an "other" category (cross hatched lines) (Source: ITC 2018).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Volume of crude oil imports into Asia Pacific nations. Volumentric shares are indicated by thickness of stream lines, Asia Pacific nations are shaded grey and exporting nations are shaded in bright colors. Inset bar chart describes the relative contributions of each exporting nation to Asia Pacific nations. Less significant exporters are binned together into an "other" category (cross hatched lines) (Source: ITC 2018).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The top 17 exporters accounted for more than 90% of the oil imports to the region. The top five importers in the region account for about 95% of imported oil, and this share is increasingly dominated by China and India (Figure 4,Figure 5). China is now the world's largest importer of crude oil importing 9.7 MMBPD. India, Japan and South Korea combined to import 10.81 MMBPD. These four countries import a total of 20.53 million BOPD of which more than 1.7 MMBPD is imported from Iran. For comparison, the US imported 7 MMBPD of crude oil and exported 2.5 MMPBD of products, and all of Europe imported 9.9 MMPD of crude oil and 0.9 MMBPD of products.

For comparison, the US imported 7 MMBPD of crude oil and exported 2.5 MMPBD of products, and all of Europe imported 9.9 MMPD of crude oil and 0.9 MMBPD of products. Figure 6 shows the net imports of crude oil and petroleum products for major exporting countries and regions along with the importing countries. Unquestionably, the Asia Pacific region is the most important oil and products importer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Net imports of crude oil and products by country, KBOPD (Source: BP 2018)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Net imports of crude oil and products by country, KBOPD (Source: BP 2018)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Given the many sources and destinations for crude oil, it was necessary to generalize oil transport distance. For most cases, we assumed Shanghai as the port of final destination, with the exception to this rule being India which exports no significant volumes of oil. Transportation for Indian oil was assumed to be internal pipelines. A summary of CI values is presented in Figure 7 with colors representing the sources of carbon emissions. Offsite emmissions may be negative when produced gas is exported and utilized.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Carbon Intensity for Asia Pacific Exporteres and Producers

formatted-caption.caption-text: Carbon Intensity for Asia Pacific Exporteres and Producers

linkTarget.anchoringText: Unconventional production in the US has grown at an astounding rate (Figure 8). Figure 9 compares carbon intensity of US unconventional oils with Asia Pacific oils. The lowest CI values come primarily from four Middle Eastern exporters and have CI values that are very low by global standards. The best AP regional producers have CI values that are still good by global standards. The average US CI value is calculated using major US unconventional crudes and assuming the export to Shanghai. The three example unconventional crudes are from a prior publication (Meehan et al. 2018) and only have transportation to the US Gulf Coast.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Historical crude production for US unconventional fields, MMB/D

formatted-caption.caption-text: Historical crude production for US unconventional fields, MMB/D
